text:
Pours copper-orange with a one finger white head with pretty nice lacing. 
Aroma is of citrus, pine, fruity notes, bready malts, sweet malts, and grassy hops. Taste is pretty similar to the aroma. Has a medium body with a semi watery, semi bitter, medium finish. Overall, a pretty nice English style pale.

Draught @ Waterfront Ale House. Lightly cloudy dark prange with small creamy off-white head, piney hops aroma, low carbonation, timid grassy hops taste, medium hoppy finish. Quite timid and smooth with little citrus influence.
Light citrus scent. Cloudy, with lots of carbonation. Minimal head some lacing.light citrus sent. Bitter taste at first, with notes of caramel and citrus. Bitter aftertaste. Very smooth mouth feel.

Enjoyable and very drinkable pale ale. On draft at the Railroad Street. Amber color with an ample white head that laced nicely around the inside of the glass. The nose was well-balanced with a good combination light and flowery hops and earthy malts. The flavors were smooth and delicious and made this beer very sessionable. A good combination of hops and malts were in the flavors, with a hint of orange, pine and earth.

12oz bottle, thanks to Vince. Bottled 3/02/15. Clear amber orange color, a bit darker for a pale ale. Good off-white head, leaving decent thicker lace. Toasty and caramel malt, mild earthy hop, touch of citrus. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of crisp lighter to moderate carbonation; sort of slick texture. Nice biscuity flavor. Moderate sweet taste, light to moderate bitter, good balance to the taste. Touch of a macro / metallic edge, but a very solid, flavorful english pale ale overall.

Reviewed from notes.
The appearance has a slightly hazy orange body with a small white head, spotty lacing is left in its wake.
The smell has citrus and hops, slight malts in the background.
The taste is sweet through malts, hops become subdued, slightly bready.
The palate is about a light to medium, some carbonation hits the tongue slightly, sessionable, bitter aftertaste and finish.
Overall, decent for the style and for me, Id probably have it again.
Copper color with a small white head. Nose is caramel and citrus. Middle is toasted grain and marmalade. Finish is earthy hop bitterness.
A very nice pale ale that is well balanced and clean. Aroma malt,hops and citrus. A nice looking beer also that is golden and has a medium white head.
Bottle. Pours a copper color with a thin white head. Piney aroma. Pretty well hopped for a pale ale. The hops come through with a grapefruit flavor throughout. Average pale ale.

Heavy hop aroma for a pale ale: pine and grapefruit, with a sweet malt undertone. Rough cream color head over lively light copper colored beer. Great bittersweet citrus flavor, very well balanced. Soft body, infinitely drinkable. One of my favorite pale ales.

On tap at Shark Finn Inn NJ. Pours a light orange color with an off-white foam head. Aroma is mostly floral and citrus hops, with some malt character. Taste is mildly hoppy with some caramel malt present.
Good beer. Nice balance and good bitter finish. Very drinkable. Solid session beer.

12 Oz. Bottle. Poured a cloudy dark amber with a little white head. Aroma is pretty good, sweet floral notes combined with caramel and fruit. Taste is also sweet, mild hops taste a little bit of bitterness towards the end. Nice beer.
From a bottle poured a copper color with a fair amount of head.  Hoppy flavor with a quick finish.

Bottled. Poured a nice hazy and verylightly filtered golden sunset brown. finger and a half of head. Nose was very pleasant with notes of pine, floral, and pineapple. Taste was a bready, with a good bittery and smooth finish. Once it warmed up, the nose was even more present with pine, and pineaple. an extremely tasty brew.

Bottle marked 010412 -- hopefully a born on date.  Nose is fresh and hoppy, beautiful juicy citrus and a little pine.  Hazy orange-amber with a fluffy off-white head.  Watery light-medium body with a little alcohol, a little nutty malt, and a bready resolution.  Hops are turned down somewhat, but theres some fine h-m balance here, minimum bitterness with a little woody pine, stinging booze up front.
I enjoyed this pale ale. it had a really nice aroma and a very crisp hop bite for a pale ale. the malts were dialed down, which is my preference.   very clean and grassy.  recommended.

Hah, I thought I tasted this before. Typical yellow beer but from a bottle it has a nice head, goes rocky after a few minutes. First taste impressions cause me to think of IPA fpr some reason.  Good co2 for a quite hoppy brew.  Yes pine or dull lemony aroma for the olfactory.  Yez, taste keeps me thinkin of ipa, certainly ventures into that territory.  Finish is same, somewhat mouth coating bitter ipa finish. I have tasted some real ipa that were much more mild than this. A little too much for my girlie lager loven  taste buds.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle. Pours clear copper with a small white head. Aroma is mild floral with a tad of pine. Nice hop bite on the flavor but not over the top.
Bottle into a goblet. Pour is a hazy brown with good lace. Aroma is citrus and pine. Taste is a very good bitter with mild malt. Finish is all hop, bitter after taste. A very good ale.

Pours a clear copper body with a one finger frothy off-white head that left a bit of lacing. The nose smells a bit more like instant iced tea more than a Pale Ale. Smells like theres going to be some crystal malt going on here. The hops are light and floral. The flavor is pretty sad. Very sweet and sugary, tastes like they dropped a packet of Sugar in the Raw in each bottle. Minimal hop flavor and bitterness. Sticky and cloying mouthfeel with fizzy carbonation. This is the worst of the Long Trail beers that Ive had.
Caramel malt, citrus, and piney hops in the aroma.  Flavor starts slightly sweet with spice and pine bitterness.  More pine bitterness in the finish.  Decent pale ale with lots of flavor.

Pours a cloudy, Rusty-colored Reddish-Orange in color. Looks almost like a "Irish Red", and not a "Pale Ale". Looks to have some spices floating around in the glass. Has a big foamy white head, that lasts for the entire glass!! When I took my last sip, and glass was empty, foam from the head was at bottom of glass!! Big foamy, long lasting head, but little to no lacing though. Has good carbonation that lasts until last sip. Aroma was of Malt and Pine, with maybe a hint of citrus. Taste was of Malt and Pine. A little bit of a Malty/Piney aftertaste as well. Not a bad Pale Ale from this small, independent brewery in Vermont! Very flavorful, but because of the somewhat Reddish color, it makes me think I am drinking an "Irish Red"!
Bottle pours a light tan head with amber color. Aroma is citrus/pine hop, medium malt-caramel with some woodiness. Taste is medium bitterness. Medium body with a dry finish. Average carbonation.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a trumpet glass to drink.  The beer had a rust-orange color with a big foamy white head that had good retention, and great lacing and cling throughout.  Its aroma had a strong pine scent blended with some citrus hops, and touches of caramel malt, barley, and grain.  Its taste had a strong bitter grainyness, with citrus and pine effects, and was just a touch sour with no sweetness.  The beer had above average carbonation and fizz, but was a bit thin with a lighter mouthfeel and slightly dry.
Bottle at Allegras dads house.  This shit is nasty.  Bitter, buttery, a tad earthy and poppy with a fair amount of soap.
for a Pale Ale, great colour, good pour, nice taste, including the aftertaste.  Overall a good beer.

Pours a cloudy orange with a finger of off-white head.  Orange citrus to the aroma.  The hops come off as mellow, though they fade up from a slight syrupy sweetness and ends with a nice hoppy bitter aftertaste.  Pretty solid.

pine and grapefruit a touch soapy but flavorful indeed. fragrant with some sweetness in bitterness some pine wafts in from time to time. touch of caramel and fruit punch with a bitter finish that lingers as the palate goes soft and smooth. Never had an English this amped up hop wise.
palish orange pour. Aroma is caramel, woods, nuts. Flavor is nutty malt and  spicy/woody hops

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle marked 100711-1703.  The pour is a cloudy copper amber color with a big head that settles down.  The aroma is well-malted with a notable Vermont pine scent.  The body is creamy. The taste is fully involved with a powerful hop finish.
nice hoppy aroma and amber in color. very nice head. good balanced taste beer
An easy going Pale Ale that has enough going for it to provide a pleasant and inoffensive drinking experience.

Long Island, NY - 12 oz bottle poured a slightly hazy amber color with moderate head and light lacing. Aroma was of citrus fruit and little sweetness. Flavor is  slightly sweet followed by citrus then the hop bitterness. Hoppiness is not overwhelming and is quite balanced. A good pale ale.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

On tap at a local restaurant. Poured into a cheater pint.

A: amber color, slight haze. Nice 1/2" off white head that reduces to a nice cap.

S: caramel, citrus, and grass

T: the bitterness from the floral/grassy hops dominate the palate followed by a splash of caramel and malt. 

M: medium bodied, slightly sticky and prickily mouth
12 ounce bottle pours a cloudy amber color, aromas of citrus, flowers, floral hops and a touch of honey.  Flavors of citrus, not a bigg hoppy bite, and a feint hint of honey and malt.
Bottle from bhensonb. Pours golden with an attractive off-white head and a citrus aroma. There is a hearty caramel malt flavor with a dry bitter hop finish. Well-balanced and drinkable.

12oz bottle.  Pours a decent off amber hue, a bit lighter than expected.  Aromas are slight citrus, floral, slight bready.  Palate is pretty straight forward and basic, some hops in the finish, but more nutty and malty up front.  Its decent, but nothing that makes me coming back for more.

12 oz bottle from Cranbury BuyRite. Poured a slightly hazy mudy orange/brown with an average frothy off white head. Aroma of honey, flowers, soap, citrus and wet cake. Medium to fuller bodied with stronger carbonation and slight touch of sourness on the finish. Flavor of  stale citrus fruit, flowers, dry caramel, hint of soap. Blah.

Nice golden copper color with an off-white frothy head.  The head thins out but does linger for a bit.  It smell of biscuit and bread, slightly sweet with a little floral and grassy hop aroma.  Overall I think this beer is very nice and balanced.  It finishes a tad dry and biscuity, but this is a good session beer.

Bottle. Pours dark red-orange, small fizzy white head. Nose is piney, with a bit of citrus, and quintessentially "British" malt profile. Taste is reflective, with a hint of English-style bitter sneaking in. A bit sharp for my tastes, but alright.
Pours a cloudy copper color with a large off-white head. Aroma of pine and citrus hops with some toasted malts. Flavor of citrus hops with some slight pine hops and malts.

UPDATED: NOV 22, 2011 Hoppy smell with malty notes. could really detect the orange. appearance was just / avg. This ale was more of the English Bitter style which I dig. That said, I sensed the pine / orange notes that the English lacks but it fit with this beer and did not offend. The palate was briefly sharp and carbd but settles throughout. I am inclined to have a couple of these (or Bass) in the fridge for the days I want a  good pale.

12oz. bottle, dated 9/8/11, which I am guessing is the bottling date rather than the "best by".  Aroma of pale, grainy, lightly sweet cereal malt and very lightly fruity, citric, herbal hop, rather fresh and enticing overall.  Mostly clear light amber color, with a creamy, lasting off-white head and very nice lacing.  Flavor profile is very nicely balanced, with more pale malt sweetness and lightly toasted grain character, joined by fruity, fresh, citric and very mildly piney hop flavors, as well as a moderate hop bitterness that arrives late to clean up the palate nicely and lend a bit of crispness.  Relatively high degree of effervescence, very lightly resinous and mineral feel, body is medium.  Incredibly drinkable, very good example of the style.  One is not likely to find much better on this side of the pond, in fact.

Pours a golden color with a thin white head.  Aroma is citrusy with pineapple and orange...a bit of straw.  Flavor has a hint of straw and caramel and lots of citrus.  Mouthfeel is lively and the finish is bitter and dry...afertaste of hoppy tea.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Giant Leesburg.  It pours a hazy amber color with a large head of off white foam.  The nose has light pine and herbal hop notes.  The flavor has a bit of pine, slight florals, and a little bit of toasted malt.  Medium bodied with slightly aggressive carbonation but a fairly dry finish.  Nice brew.
Bottle thanks to Warren. Pours copper with white head. Nose/taste of sweet and caramel malt, tropical fruit and hops. Medium body.

bottle poured a light amber in color with a thin white ring of head. aroma has a nice hit of hops, light citrus, pines, and some malt. mouth feel is a medium and there is plenty of carbonation. flavor picks up mostly bitter side hops, citrus pokes, malt, and a bit of minerals in the finish.
A tart pale ale, very herbal, and invigorating palate. One of my favorite pale ales!

Bottle 355 ml 
Aroma:  great note ,frontal hop dryness, pine , spruce , green grassy feel. Superbly fresh. 8+
Appearance: great pour. Pleasant to eye crystal clear dark amber with large frothy white top. Fine ornamental lace.4+ 
Body , Flavour , Palate and Final Notes:  Medium full bodied. Dry but overly, crisp ,clean palate. Bitter yet smooth with herbal and pine notes. Straight to the point. I have not had such clean cut brew in a long time. Solid if not world class bitter amber ale.
Hoppier than the IPA!? This beer was very nice and enjoyable, the hops were in abundance and it had a bold full flavor for a pale ale, somewhat like Sierra Nevada.
Pours a cloudy copper color with a white head.  Aroma of sweet malt and hops.  Caramel malt, pine,citrus and hops comprise the flavor of a surprisingly good beer.

<br clear="left">Almost every brewery brews a pale ale - whether its a micro brewpub, a major craft brewery, or one of the macros "imprint" lines. Its almost like its a requirement to get a brewers license. The style is usually solid and appeals to people of different taste ranges since its flavorful, but not extremely robust, and drinkable but not watery. Its hard to make a pale ale that really stands out, but Long Trail Pale Ale comes pretty close. APPEARANCE AND AROMAI poured a 12oz bottle into an English pint glass. This beer forms a huge head of rocky, off-white foam that leaves plenty of lacing on the glass. The color is a hazy shade of orange to copper and is extremely bubbly. The aroma is surprisingly citrusy, with some noticeable floral notes as well. It could easily be mistaken for an IPA from the scent alone.TASTEI should "disclaim" this review by mentioning I was drinking a beer that was bottled six months before I drank it. I was worried the beer mightve gone bad but was genuinely surprised by how flavorful it was. Usually, American pale ales just satisfy me, but Long Trail Pale Ale went a little above and beyond and actually impressed me. Much like the aroma, the first swig had the hop bite of an IPA. Its a clean, citrusy hop with a candy-like sweetness in the finish. The bitterness lingers for only a moment or two, leaving your palate clean in the end.Perhaps it was due to the fact I was drinking old beer, but I definitely noticed the flavor mellowed out about halfway through. The palate didnt change, as the clean hop taste shone through, but the intensity seemed to be muted. The bitterness increased and became a bit drier. Still, this is more than I can say for many beers of the style so it was still pleasing.DRINKABILITYLong Trail Pale Ale is not too thick and definitely not too thin in terms of mouthfeel. The body is perfectly medium bordering on the light side. It goes down smooth and finishes clean.Believe it or not, I couldnt find the ABV statistic for this beer anywhere. Id estimate its around 5.5% since its too robust to be much lighter, but doesnt have the density of something heavier like an IPA. It would make a great session beer, especially for hopheads, and pair well with dinner.FINAL THOUGHTSLong Trail is one of those mid-level craft breweries known for making pedestrian beers of pedestrian styles and technically you could say that true for their Pale Ale. However, Im impressed the brewery was able to add an extra touch to this brew and make it a little more memorable.

Pours a lightly hazed, amber/bronze body under a spongy, cream-colored head that holds. Aroma of lemon, pine and light florals. Flavor leaves no real impression on me. While sometimes hops and malts can be harmonious, in this case they kind of just cancel each other out. Resiny lemon lingers in the finish, but as a whole this just seems a bit amateurish. ~~~~~~~~ Variety 12 pk./12 oz. btls., random bottleshop, Paoli, PA
Pours a golden yellow with slight carbonation. Aroma is hops, pine and citrus fruit. Taste is a nice light balance of floral pine and fruit with a hop and carbonation kick on the back end.
12 oz. bottle. Orange/amber colour, nice deep hue, creamy head. Aroma is citrus and pine. Tastes of piney hops and mild malt. Overall an enjoyable ale without being too heavy.
Draft at County Grill.  Bright amber with a decent head.  Musty and malty with a nice hoppy little citric twist at the finish.  Most definitely sessionable and aimed at the masses.  (4131, 6/11/2011)

Bottle.  Semi hazy copper color with a small white head.  Aroma is caramel, grassy hops, and some orange citrus.  Pretty nice.  Taste is fairly bitter throughout.  Some toast, grapefruit, and marmalade.  Some grassy earthiness is present too.  Medium bodied.  Overall this is pretty solid beer and pretty easy to drink.

A - Pours a bright clear copper-orange color with a finger of crisp frothy white head atop. The head fades down to a still sizeable layer leaving behind lots of lacing.

S - The aroma is a mix of sweet malts and citrus hops. There is also a bit of grassy hops as well.

T - Starts off with some citrus hops and sweet caramel malts. Through the middle some grassy hops and bitterness come through as well. The finish is a mix of citrus hops and bitterness and a bit of caramel malts that linger.

M - Medium bodied with moderate carbonation. Very smooth and crisp. The finish is a bit bitter with some nice dryness.

D - Very drinkable. The flavors are nice and balanced with a good hop and malt balance. The beer is very crisp and does feel too thin or watery.
(bottle)  Clear copper color, with small white head.  Aroma of hops and flowers.  Slightly bitter hop flavor.  Somewhat watery.   A good price point for this quality, as usual for this brewer.
UPDATED: JUL 10, 2011 Pours yellow with white pillowy head.  Aroma is pine, pine and resin.  Taste is bitter with some caramel sweetness.  Surprised by the bitterness, in a good way.

On tap at Circa, High Bridge, NJ.  Clean lines.  Beer pours deep gold with a medium head retention.  Aroma is of herbal hops mixed with some citrus notes and a bit of grain.  Attack is relatively mild for a pale ale, but well-balanced with mild maltiness and a clean finish.  Good table beer for sure.

12oz. Im not sure where the English Pale Ale designation is coming from. This has a serious hop bite to it.  Its definitely not IPA territory, but Id call this American Pale Ale.  The aroma is piney hops, and not much malt sweetness at all. The flavor is similar in that the focus is on the hops and the malts come in a distant second place.  The body is light and the mouth-feel is very dry hop spiciness.  Not a bad beer by any stretch, but Im really thrown by the classification.

Hoppy and hoppier.  In a blind taste test I would steer towards the Ipa category.  this is an awesome pale ale.  giant head the towers over the brew at first.  Im thinking the abv is around 5.5 or so.  Flows nicely on the pallate with citrus, hay, and malt notes prevalent.  Color is amazingly bold for a pale ale.  A mild sunlight shown through a sterdy barn in the morning hours.  This is my favorite pale ale.
UPDATED: MAY 16, 2011 has a surprising hop bite to it, background is of a clean light lager, very easy drinking

12 oz bottle.
Pours bronze with a head that thins to white foamy.
Nice citrus -lime aroma.
Moderately strong bouquet of lime zest and pine.
A nice pale ale. Not too hoppy.

From bottle. Happy with orange, grass, and some diacetyl. A bit of oxidation. Sweet pale malt. Deep golden clear with light chill haze, topped with off-white foamy lacing head. Medium body with medium carbonation. Starts medium sweet with pale malt, light crystal, and a bit of oxidation. Hoppy profile, with light fruity notes, orange peel, mild grassy notes. Finish is fruity-bitter, with smooth bitter after.
Pours amber with a small tan head.  Smells of citrus, some floral hints.  Tastes resiny with some sweet citrussy notes and some earthiness on the finish.

12 ounce bottle from State Line Liquors. Pours a clear amber color with a large frothy white head. Decent head rentention and lacing. Aroma of hops... leafy, floral with a faint bit of citrus. No malts to speak of. The taste is bitter floral and citrus hops with pale malts. Medium bodied. Decent.

from Mondial de la Bière, Strasbourg - hazy amber-orange colour with a chaotic foam left; fairly hoppy aroma with notes of oranges and grapefruit; medium-bodied and quite astringent, dry and fairly bitter; long fruity hoppy finish

Bottle. Bronze colored pour with a short, off-white head. Aroma is light citrus, spicy hops, floral notes, tea leaves and earthy notes. Taste is spicy hops, citrus fruit, earthy notes, caramel, and floral notes. Body is medium with a soft, bubbly carbonation. Ends with more big hop spiciness and floral notes, sweet malt, earthy notes, tea leaves, and citrus fruit.

Moderately strong bouquet of lime zest and pine. Clear amber, thin head. Piney lime flavor. Fairly good use of whatever hop produces the lime aroma and flavor, perhaps citra? Not overbearing with lime but quite a hoppy APA. One of my favorites from Long Trail.
Tap.  Yellow color, thick white head.  Absolutely amazing aroma of fresh pine forest - holy cow!  Taste is very bitter, with plenty of resin and pine.  Good stuff.
Copper colored with white head.  Light citrus and pine aroma.  Light malty taste with crisp citrus finish.

on tap-pours a light tan head that laces with amber color.  Aroma is citrus/pine hops, medium malt-caramel.  Taste is pine/citrus-orange/grapefruit hop bite, medium malt-caramel.  Drying finish.  OK carbonation.

I expect an IPA to be a little hopper than this. Something slightly off in the finish, its slightly metallic and oily. Aside from these minor flaws, its sprightly and refreshing, with bright citrusy hop notes. Not mind blowing, but nothing from Long Trail is.

On tap at Maggies on the River, in Watertown, NY. Served a nice golden color with a nice head with good retention and lacing. Has a mild malt and grainy citrus aroma. Not overpowering, inviting. Has a citrus & malt flavor with nice crisp bitterness to round things out. Quite refreshing.
medium body, crisp & clean. A well balanced brew. Hits the spot. Very smooth and easy drinker. Had a couple with lunch only wish I had time for a few more.

On tap at the Red Parrot in Newport.  It started off promising with a fluffy off white head capping the golden ale.  It went down hill from there.  The pale ale is kinda piney, but not the good over the top uber hoppy piny and resiny flavor of a DIPA.  But rather a fail hearted tease that just pisses you off and almost skunks the beer...
Two 12oz bottles in a frosted mug, poured deep copper with a frothy head good malt aroma and taste.  Light citrus and pine notes.  Malty flavor good english stlye ale

Sampled on draft at the Rivertowne Pub this beer poured a vibrant orange-amber color with a medium sized creamy off white head that lingered and produced good lacing. The aroma was faint tart lemon and orange. The flavor was tart and bitter with notes of lemon, orange and faint caramel. The finish was medium length tart citrus. A touch thin in body. Ok.

Bottle. Pours golden  with an average white head. Aromas of pine and hopss. Taste is crisp with a moderate bitter pine, this is offset slightly by the subtle sweetness of the malts. Surprisingly good.

Bottle.  Pours a clear golden color with a white head.  Nose is light piney hops, a hint of citrus, and light malts.  A bit watery, citrus hops come out more than in the nose, still some pine supporting.  A decent balance between the hops and the malt - I just wish there was more.
Pours a golden yellow with slight carbonation.  Aroma is hops, pine and citrus fruit.  Taste is a nice light balance of floral pine and fruit with a hop and carbonation kick on the back end.

Bottle. Pours a clean copper color with a slight haze and a nice frothy off white head which leaves light lacing and a thin film. Nose is fresh, fruity hops with light apricots and a light caramel malt note. Light hints of toffee and sweetness. Palate is crisp, nice carbonation and a touch of stickiness on the tongue. Flavor is floral, sticky, resiny hops with a nice fruit note of apricots and a clean finish.

Bottle from Summer 12-pack. Orange-amber clear body with a tannish-white head that quickly disappears. Some nice lacing too. This is a really fresh, grassy and piney beer with slight red apple notes. The beer has a blended palate that is quenching and biting at the same time. Really good session beer.

draft @ McGarretts, Buffalo, NY. Pours a nice orange/amber. Aroma is piney hops, light citrus. Taste delivers a good initial hop burst but falls off. Decent but flavor drops off too much from initial hit

Location: Sampled at the NY Brewfest on Governors Island, 6/19/10


Aroma: The nose has some caramel, pine, yeast, and grass

Appearance: Pours a golden-like color with a white head

Flavor: Taste is balanced, but dull, light, grainy, slightly sweet, lightly bitter

Palate: The body is fairly light, its crisp, solid, and drinkable

Overall Impression: 
This beer was alright, but I just wasnt overly excited by it.  Basically, it is just a boring pale ale with a mild, not so exciting, flavor.
Draft in a shaker.  An alright pale ale.  Too malty on the flavor and aroma.  Some hops.  Light on the palate.  Average.

Draft during Frank Smith Beerapalooza 2010.  Dark straw pour w white head.  Nose was pale malt, hopcitrus, earthy dusty.  Tastes earthy hoppy, not crisp or resiny, with a solid malt bill and a smooth finish.

Pours amber into a shaker. Bright white head with excellent retention recedes to coat surface. Tropical fruit and pine resin aromas.  Medium bodied with slightly sour fruit upfront turning to spruce in the lasting bitter finish.

Pours a clear golden amber color with a thick white head.  Aroma is of pine, hops, caramel, bark, and resin.  Flavor is of caramel, hops, raisin, malts, and slight citrus.  Leaves a sweeter hop finish.  Pretty much a session style pale ale.

Bottle.  Golden pour with a white head.  Smell is pine and grapefruit.  Some pine in the taste, definitely hoppy.  Crisp mouthfeel.  Surprisingly good, another good offering from Long Trail.  Not sure what else there is to say.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée au Beverage Warehouse (Winooski, VT). Arôme: Légère odeur dagrumes et de caramel. Apparence: La couleur est orangée légèrement voilée avec une moyenne densité de bulle. Présence dun moyen col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de pamplemousse avec une pointe dhoublons résineux. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture minérale. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Arrière goût houblonné. (Rating #3013)

Draught at Capones:  Aroma of crystal malt, light hops, and slight pine.  Poured amber/gold in color with a large, creamy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Clear. Slightly to lightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is lightly sweet and slightly bitter.  Tastes of grain, crystal malt, slight hops, and slight diacetyl.  Medium body.  Smooth texture.  Average carbonation.  Grain and malt finish.  A below-average APA.

Strong aroma of pine with a bitter flavor that is surprisingly drinkable.  Not quite as hoppy as a lot of pale ales, this instead gives you an image of the evergreen of Vermont.  Finshes well with some bitterness but no harshess.

Bottle. Clear orange-gold with attractive, persistent off-white head. Aromas of caramel, grass, citrus and pine. Flavors of caramel, toast, pine, lemon peel and herbs. Sweet, salty and bitter finish.  Thin body with slick mouthfeel and soft, moderate carbonation. Fine new offering.

Bottle.  Pours a clear orange with a thick, foamy white head.  Aroma of diacetyl, light citrus, sweet malt.  Flavor of more light diacetyl with lemon, citrus, hop resins, sweet fruits, bready malt and caramel malt.  Smooth, creamy palate.  Great English IPA and superbly drinkable.  A great new addition from Long Trail!
7/4/8/4/15 [3.8/5]
